thread.title: US, European stocks soar on US interest rate hopes
thread.title_full: US, European stocks soar on US interest rate hopes | The Australian

author: Dow Jones
title: US, European stocks soar on US interest rate hopes
text:
At the closing bell, the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 304 points, or 1.9 per cent, to 16,776, building on Friday’s 200-point rise.
The S & P 500 gained 1.8 per cent, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 1.6 per cent.
European stock markets also rose strongly as the weak US data fuelled talk the US Federal Reserve would not hike interest rates any time soon.
The Australian market looks set to open sharply higher following the rallies in US and European stocks. At 6.45am (AEDT), the December share price index futures contract was up 68 points at 5,209.
Investors have been reassessing the timeline for interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve in the months ahead following report on Friday night (AEDT) that the US economy added fewer jobs than expected in September.
US stocks tumbled immediately after the report, only to reverse course and push higher into Monday.
“It’s a follow-through from Friday’s reversal rally,” Bill Nichols, head of US equities at Cantor Fitzgerald, said of the overnight (AEDT) gains. Contributing to the gains was a rebound in commodity prices, he said. He said the September jobs number will likely be revised higher in the months ahead, as has been the case in the past.
“You have to be cautious either way,” he said. “The economy is probably okay, but you can make the case that there are growth concerns.”
Energy stocks posted some of the widest gains Monday as oil prices continued their recent climb. Crude oil prices rose 1.6 per cent to $US46.26 in New York. Financial stocks also rose.
Ultra-low interest rates have buoyed shares in the US for years, but worries over slowing growth overseas have prompted a pullback in recent months. Labour market strength is one of the factors the US Federal Reserve looks at when deciding whether to raise interest rates.
The Stoxx Europe 600 rose 3 per cent, led by gains in energy stocks that were buoyed by steadying oil prices. Germany’s DAX added 2.8 per cent. France’s CAC index rose 3.5 per cent.
“The weekend has given traders the time to digest the weaker-than-expected jobs report on Friday and it seems we are back with ‘bad news is good news’ for the equity markets,” Jonathan Sudaria, night dealer at London Capital Group, said.
US Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren said on Saturday that his confidence that the central bank can raise rates soon had fallen after the jobs report came in well below economists’ expectations.
The yield on 10-year US Treasurys rose to 2.021 per cent as prices declined.
Financial markets rising reflect investor expectations that the Federal Reserve will delay raising interest rates off rock bottom, according to Tim Crockford, a fund manager at Hermès Investment Management.
“The Fed still remains the main provider of liquidity to markets. It definitely has an effect on equities and all asset prices,” Mr Crockford said.
In Asia, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng and Japan’s Nikkei 225 both ended up 1.6 per cent. Stock markets in mainland China were closed for a holiday.
Some investors said they expected more stimulus from Beijing following weak economic data in the region. The World Bank downgraded its economic growth forecasts for the East Asia and Pacific region, and China’s expected growth rate was cut to 6.9 per cent from 7.1 per cent.
Investors in Europe were also considering the results of Portugal’s elections. Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho, who oversaw years of unpopular austerity measures, finished far ahead of his Socialist rival, but his centre-right coalition lost its majority in Parliament.
Dow Jones
